I failed a course and drift through life in this village, caught in a state of stagnation and idleness. There is between me and these people from the village
an indifference that I cannot overcome. My desire is to leave soon. But I don’t see how. And when the
present is bleak and the future uncertain, the past always comes to mind as the time when we were happy.
That’s why I’ve become Master Finezas’s confidant.
He helps me relive my memories by recounting the days he calls his “glory days.” We are
alone in his shop. Razor in hand, Master Finezas recites entire scenes from "the greatest dramas
ever written." And within him lies such a profound longing for the nights when he made love and sorrow weep with sobs, the
ladies of the village that, oftentimes, he forgets all that surrounds him and remains, for a long while, motionless. His eyes
